unnormalised: ## My tryst with IT: From BASIC to the Cloud
normalised: My tryst with I-T: From B-A-S-I-C to the Cloud

unnormalised: My first brush with IT wasn't exactly glamorous. Picture this: a dusty computer lab in my school in Patna, circa 1998. The hum of ancient machines, the smell of warm plastic, and the dreaded DOS prompt staring back at me. We were learning BASIC, and honestly, I thought it was the most boring thing ever. I’d rather be outside playing cricket, or maybe even studying History instead! But my dad, a railway engineer, insisted it was the future. He’d say things like, "Rohan, beta, computers are the future of Bharat! You have to learn this."

I’d rather be outside playing cricket, or maybe even studying History instead! But my dad, a railway engineer, insisted it was the future. He’d say things like, "Rohan, beta, computers are the future of Bharat! You have to learn this."

unnormalised: My initial attempts were disastrous. Syntax errors galore! I remember spending hours trying to get a simple "Hello World" program to run, only to be defeated by a misplaced comma or a rogue space. "Error 404: Brain not found," my friends would joke. It was frustrating, but something about the logic intrigued me. The idea that you could give instructions and a machine would actually follow them was kind of magical, even on a monochrome screen.

The idea that you could give instructions and a machine would actually follow them was kind of magical, even on a monochrome screen.

unnormalised: My turning point came during a summer vacation. I stumbled upon a book about HTML and web design. Suddenly, computers weren't just about boring commands; they were about creating things, sharing ideas, connecting with the world. I spent hours poring over the book, experimenting with tags, and building my first (hideously designed) website. I even managed to convince my uncle, who ran a small grocery store, to let me create a website for his business. He wasn’t entirely sure what a website was, but he trusted me. I think he paid me ₹500 for the effort.

unnormalised: Fast forward a few years, and I was enrolling in IIT Delhi for my B.Tech in Computer Science. The change was unreal. From BASIC on ancient machines to cutting-edge research and high-speed internet, it was like stepping into a different dimension. I remember the Wi-Fi speeds were advertised as 100 Mbps, which blew my mind after years of dial-up.

I remember the Wi-Fi speeds were advertised as one hundred M-b-p-s, which blew my mind after years of dial-up.

unnormalised: My time at IIT exposed me to a whole new world of IT: Java, C++, data structures, algorithms. I even dabbled in AI, trying to build a chatbot that could understand Bhojpuri! The projects were challenging, the deadlines were tight, and the pressure was immense, but I thrived. The late nights spent coding with friends, fueled by endless cups of chai, are some of my fondest memories.

unnormalised: Post-IIT, I landed a job at Infosys in Bangalore. It was a good starting point, a stable job, and decent pay. But after a couple of years, I felt like I was just a cog in a machine. The work was repetitive, the bureaucracy was stifling, and I yearned for something more. I wanted to be part of something innovative, something disruptive.

unnormalised: That's when I decided to take the plunge and join a startup. It was a small company, just a handful of people working out of a cramped office in Koramangala. But the energy was palpable. We were building a mobile app for farmers, connecting them directly to markets and providing them with real-time information. The tech stack involved Python, AWS, and a whole lot of caffeine.

unnormalised: The startup life was a roller coaster. We faced countless challenges: funding shortages, technical glitches, and intense competition. But we persevered. We worked tirelessly, fueled by a shared passion for our mission. We launched the app, and it slowly started gaining traction. Farmers in rural Maharashtra and Karnataka began using it, and we started seeing a real impact.

unnormalised: Now, I work as a cloud architect for a multinational corporation, helping businesses migrate their operations to the cloud. I specialize in Azure and often consult on projects utilizing kubernetes. It's a far cry from those dusty computer labs in Patna, but the core principles remain the same: problem-solving, innovation, and a relentless pursuit of knowledge. I still keep up with the latest trends in IT, attending conferences and reading blogs (especially those written in Python!).

unnormalised: My journey in IT has been long and winding, full of unexpected twists and turns. But looking back, I'm grateful for every experience, every challenge, and every setback. It's all shaped me into the person I am today, a techie who's passionate about using technology to make a positive impact on the world. And it all started with that dreaded DOS prompt and a misplaced comma in a BASIC program. Who knew?
